runs.prompt_snippet: I need a quick risk analysis for the 'Microsoft_Stock' datas...
runs.full_response_text:
<response>
## Dataset Fields Identified

The 'Microsoft_Stock' dataset contains these columns relevant for forecasting:

| Column | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| **Date** | Timestamp (time series index) |
| **Close** | Closing price (target variable for forecasting) |
| Open | Opening price |
| High | Daily high price |
| Low | Daily low price |
| Volume | Trading volume |
| KEY | Series identifier |

---

## 10-Day Probabilistic Forecast (MSFT Close Price)

| Day | Date | Lower Bound (10%) | Median Forecast | Upper Bound (90%) | Forecast Range ($) |
|-----|------|-------------------|-----------------|-------------------|-------------------|
| 1 | Apr 1, 2021 | $231.06 | $235.85 | $241.51 | 10.45 |
| 2 | Apr 2, 2021 | $230.89 | $236.73 | $241.87 | 10.98 |
| 3 | Apr 3, 2021 | $230.71 | $236.73 | $242.58 | 11.87 |
| 4 | Apr 4, 2021 | $230.53 | $237.62 | $243.64 | 13.11 |
| 5 | Apr 5, 2021 | $230.53 | $237.62 | $244.35 | 13.82 |
| 6 | Apr 6, 2021 | $230.53 | $237.62 | $244.53 | 14.00 |
| 7 | Apr 7, 2021 | $230.53 | $238.50 | $245.41 | 14.88 |
| 8 | Apr 8, 2021 | $231.24 | $239.39 | $246.65 | 15.41 |
| 9 | Apr 9, 2021 | $230.53 | $239.39 | $247.54 | 17.01 |
| 10 | Apr 10, 2021 | $230.18 | $239.39 | $248.25 | 18.07 |

---

## Risk Interpretation

**Moderate-Upward Trend with Expanding Volatility**

- **Directional Bias:** The median forecast shows a gradual upward trend from ~$236 to ~$239 over 10 days (+1.4%), suggesting mild bullish momentum.
- **Increasing Uncertainty:** The prediction band widens significantly from $10.45 to $18.07 (73% expansion), indicating compounding risk over time.
- **Lower Bound Stability:** The 10th percentile remains relatively flat (~$230-231), providing a potential support level with ~$5-6 downside from the last close (~$236).
- **Upper Bound Momentum:** The 90th percentile rises from ~$241.50 to ~$248.25, suggesting upside potential if favorable conditions persist.

**Risk Recommendation:** The expanding forecast range signals that risk accumulates over the 10-day horizon. Investors should consider position sizing and stop-loss levels around the $230 support zone while monitoring for volatility spikes.
</response>

<feedback>
The dataset_info tool worked well to quickly retrieve column metadata without needing to load the full dataset. The chronos_inference_pretrained function efficiently generated a 10-day probabilistic forecast with custom quantiles in just over 2 seconds. The bolt-small model delivered clear median and bound estimates suitable for risk analysis.

Minor improvement opportunities:
- The tool could optionally return the next forecast dates automatically (I had to manually calculate from the last dataset date).
- Adding volatility metrics (e.g., measured spread as % of median) directly in the output would benefit risk assessment workflows.
</feedback>

The data was collected from my apartment unit in San Jose for one plus year. The data is collected with smart meters and shared by the energy company. This is time-series data by nature and can be used for various time-series Machine Learning experiments.

Description of Data
The data contains eight attributes.

TYPE - This is an information column. The value is 'Electric usage' for all the observations.
DATE - Date of electric consumption. There is no timestamp in this field.
START TIME - Start time of the consumption.
END TIME - End time of the consumption
USAGE - Consumption in kWh
UNITS - This column denotes measurement unit. It is kWh for all the observations.
COST - Cost of consumption in $.
NOTES - Mostly an empty column

runs.prompt_snippet: I have a specialized fine-tuned forecasting model named 'Mic...
runs.full_response_text:
<summary>
Both forecasts completed successfully. Fine-tuned model ran in 7.15s; pre-trained baseline in 1.30s. Calculating uncertainty intervals for comparison.
</summary>

<feedback>
The tools worked well together. model_details provided crucial schema information confirming the column names match. Both inference functions returned execution times and quantile bounds needed for comparison.
</feedback>

<response>
Forecast Comparison (7-day, 10th/90th percentiles):

| Day | Fine-Tuned Forecast | Interval Width | Pre-trained Forecast | Interval Width |
|-----|---------------------|----------------|----------------------|----------------|
| 1   | 233.94 | 6.57 | 235.85 | 10.45 |
| 2   | 235.53 | 6.45 | 236.73 | 10.98 |
| 3   | 236.48 | 6.72 | 236.73 | 11.87 |
| 4   | 238.08 | 9.19 | 237.62 | 13.11 |
| 5   | 238.40 | 5.19 | 237.62 | 13.82 |
| 6   | 238.72 | 5.32 | 237.62 | 14.00 |
| 7   | 238.39 | 6.75 | 238.50 | 14.88 |

**(a) Uncertainty Intervals:**
Fine-tuned model - tighter/more confident
- Average interval width: ~6.60
- Consistently narrower across all 7 days

Pre-trained baseline - wider/more uncertain
- Average interval width: ~13.40
- Intervals widen noticeably over horizon (10.45 → 14.88)
- ~2x wider than fine-tuned model

**(b) Execution Time:**
- Fine-tuned: 7.15 seconds
- Pre-trained: 1.30 seconds
- Pre-trained is ~5.5x faster

Summary: The fine-tuned model produces significantly tighter uncertainty bounds (higher confidence) at the cost of slower inference. The pre-trained baseline runs much faster but with much wider uncertainty intervals.
</response>

<response>
## Dataset Fields Identified

| **Close** | Target variable for forecasting |

---

## 10-Day Probabilistic Forecast (Microsoft Stock - Close Price)

| Day | Median (50th%) | Lower (10th%) | Upper (90th%) | Spread |
|-----|----------------|---------------|---------------|--------|
| 1 | $235.85 | $231.06 | $241.51 | $10.45 |
| 2 | $236.73 | $230.89 | $241.87 | $10.98 |
| 3 | $236.73 | $230.71 | $242.58 | $11.87 |
| 4 | $237.62 | $230.53 | $243.64 | $13.11 |
| 5 | $237.62 | $230.53 | $244.35 | $13.82 |
| 6 | $237.62 | $230.53 | $244.53 | $14.00 |
| 7 | $238.50 | $230.53 | $245.41 | $14.88 |
| 8 | $239.39 | $231.24 | $246.65 | $15.41 |
| 9 | $239.39 | $230.53 | $247.54 | $17.01 |
| 10 | $239.39 | $230.18 | $248.25 | $18.07 |

---

## Risk Interpretation

**Trend:** Slight upward trajectory (+1.5% over 10 days), indicating modest bullish momentum.

**Volatility:** The prediction interval widens from ~$10.45 on Day 1 to ~$18.07 on Day 10—a **73% increase in uncertainty**. At Day 10, the 10th-90th percentile range represents approximately **7.6% of the median price**, signaling moderate but growing risk.

**Risk Assessment:** The model projects narrow short-term uncertainty that expands meaningfully by Day 10. Conservative positions should consider the upper bound (~$248) as a near-term resistance level, with downside risk bottoming around $230 under the lower-tail scenario. Overall: **low-to-moderate risk** for short-term holding, with increasing uncertainty for longer horizons.
</response>

<feedback>
The dataset_info and inference tools worked smoothly. For stock risk analysis, it would be helpful to have:
1. Historical volatility metrics computed automatically for context
2. Tail risk indicators (e.g., VaR at 5th/95th percentiles as an additional option)
3. A one-click risk score that combines trend, volatility, and spread dynamics
This would enable faster risk interpretation without manual calculations.
</feedback>

END TIME - End time of the consumption

UNITS - This column denotes measurement unit. It is kWh for all the observations.
COST - Cost of consumption in $.
NOTES - Mostly an empty column

runs.full_response_text:
<summary>
Successfully generated both 7-day forecasts:

**Fine-tuned Model Analysis:**
- Execution time: 6.81 seconds
- Model: Microsoft_Forecaster (t5 architecture, ~176 MB)
- 10th/90th percentile bounds available
- Average uncertainty interval width: $5.93 across 7 days

**Pre-trained Model Analysis:**
- Execution time: 0.81 seconds  
- Model: Chronos-bolt-small (bolt architecture)
- 10th/90th percentile bounds available
- Average uncertainty interval width: $12.86 across 7 days
</summary>

<feedback>
The tools worked well for this analysis:
- model_versions and model_details provided clear schema information confirming the fine-tuned model expects Date, Open, High, Low, Close, Volume, KEY columns with "Close" as default target
- dataset_info confirmed the dataset structure matches the model's expected input signature
- Both inference tools executed successfully and returned uncertainty bounds as requested
- The fine-tuned model used custom sampling parameters (num_samples, temperature, top_k, top_p), while the bolt architecture ignored these
</feedback>

<response>
**Forecast Comparison (7-day Microsoft Stock Close Price Predictions)**

## Uncertainty Intervals:
**Fine-tuned Model (Microsoft_Forecaster):** TIGHTER bounds
- Average interval width: **$5.93**
- Range across 7 days: $5.16 - $6.86
- More confident predictions with narrower prediction bands

**Pre-trained Baseline (Chronos-bolt-small):** WIDER bounds  
- Average interval width: **$12.86**
- Range across 7 days: $10.31 - $14.88
- Broader uncertainty, ~117% wider than fine-tuned model

## Execution Time:
**Fine-tuned Model:** 6.81 seconds
**Pre-trained Model:** 0.81 seconds

The pre-trained model is **8.4x faster** but produces significantly wider uncertainty intervals, indicating the domain-specialized fine-tuned model learned more precise patterns from Microsoft stock data, albeit at higher computational cost.
</response>

## Dataset Fields for Forecasting

For the **Microsoft_Stock** dataset (Apr 2015 - Mar 2021), the relevant fields are:

| Field | Purpose |
|-------|---------|
| **Date** | Timestamp for time series analysis |
| **Close** | Target variable for forecasting (selected as primary price metric) |
| Open/High/Low | Supporting price context (optional) |
| Volume | Market activity indicator (optional) |

---

## 10-Day Probabilistic Forecast (Microsoft Stock Close Price)

| Day | Median Forecast | Lower Bound (10%) | Upper Bound (90%) | Price Range (Width) |
|-----|-----------------|-------------------|-------------------|---------------------|
| 1 | $235.85 | $231.06 | $241.51 | $10.45 |
| 2 | $236.73 | $230.89 | $241.87 | $10.98 |
| 3 | $236.73 | $230.71 | $242.58 | $11.87 |

| 9 | $239.39 | $230.53 | $247.54 | $17.01 |
| 10 | $239.39 | $230.18 | $248.25 | $18.07 |

---

## Risk Interpretation

| Risk Metric | Assessment |
|-------------|------------|
| **Trend Bias** | Slight upward bias (+1.5% median over 10 days) |
| **Uncertainty Growth** | Bound width expands by ~73% from Day 1 to Day 10, reflecting typical forecast horizon uncertainty |
| **Downside Risk** | Lower bound ~$230-$231 (potential -2.3% downside from start) |
| **Volatility Indicator** | Growing spread (10.45 → 18.07) suggests market uncertainty increases with horizon—expected for equities |

**Summary**: The forecast indicates modest upside potential with moderate volatility risk. The widening prediction interval over time is normal for short-term equity forecasts. Conservative positioning would account for the worst-case ~$230 level.

</response>

<feedback>
The tools worked effectively for this task:
- dataset_info provided clear metadata about column names and structure
- chronos_inference_pretrained generated probabilistic forecasts quickly (~1 second)
- The lower_quantile/upper_quantile parameters correctly produced the 10th/90th percentile bounds

Suggested improvements:
1. Include forecast dates (not just day numbers) in the output for better readability
2. Add automatic calculation of percentage changes or volatility metrics in the response
3. Return confidence metrics or model performance indicators
</feedback>

runs.full_response_text:
<summary>
1. Retrieved model versions for 'Microsoft_Forecaster' - found version 1
2. Got model details showing T5 architecture, signature with Date/Close/etc columns, default value_column='Close'
3. Retrieved 'Microsoft_Stock' dataset metadata - 1511 rows, columns Date, Open, High, Low, Close, Volume, KEY
4. Generated 7-day forecast using fine-tuned model with 10th/90th percentiles
5. Generated 7-day forecast using pre-trained Chronos-bolt-small baseline with 10th/90th percentiles
6. Analyzed uncertainty interval widths and execution times for comparison
</summary>

<feedback>
- The tools worked well with clear separation between fine-tuned and pre-trained inference
- Execution times were captured in metadata, enabling direct comparison
- Uncertainty bounds were returned as lower_bound and upper_bound, making analysis straightforward
- Schema validation for fine-tuned models is important - the model required exact column matching
- The pre-trained model uses 'bolt' architecture which ignores sampling parameters (num_samples, temperature, top_k, top_p) - this is good to know but doesn't affect forecast comparison
</feedback>

<response>
**Model Analysis:**
- Microsoft_Forecaster: Version 1, created 2025-12-17, T5 architecture, ~184MB
- Schema requires: Date, Open, High, Low, Close, Volume, KEY

**Forecast Results (7-day, Close price):**

| Day | Fine-tuned Forecast | [10th, 90th] | Interval Width | Pre-trained Baseline | [10th, 90th] | Interval Width |
|-----|---------------------|-------------|----------------|---------------------|-------------|----------------|
| 1 | 236.52 | [233.30, 238.58] | 5.28 | 235.85 | [231.06, 241.51] | 10.45 |
| 2 | 236.18 | [230.89, 238.89] | 8.00 | 236.73 | [230.89, 241.87] | 10.98 |
| 3 | 235.84 | [232.61, 240.37] | 7.76 | 236.73 | [230.71, 242.58] | 11.87 |
| 4 | 236.80 | [234.08, 239.39] | 5.31 | 237.62 | [230.53, 243.64] | 13.11 |
| 5 | 236.46 | [234.39, 239.83] | 5.44 | 237.62 | [230.53, 244.35] | 13.82 |
| 6 | 236.77 | [233.53, 240.02] | 6.49 | 237.62 | [230.53, 244.53] | 14.00 |
| 7 | 239.03 | [236.30, 240.33] | 4.03 | 238.50 | [230.53, 245.41] | 14.88 |

**Avg Interval Width:** Fine-tuned: 6.05 | Baseline: 12.73

**Execution Time:** Fine-tuned: 6.7s | Baseline: 0.7s

**Comparison:**

(a) **Uncertainty Intervals:** The fine-tuned model produces significantly tighter uncertainty bounds (average width 6.05 vs 12.73, ~53% narrower). The baseline model's uncertainty grows substantially over the horizon, while the fine-tuned model's remains more consistent.

(b) **Execution Time:** The fine-tuned model is ~9.3x slower (6.7s vs 0.7s) due to its larger T5 architecture vs the lightweight bolt baseline.

**Key Takeaway:** The specialized fine-tuned model offers better forecast precision at higher computational cost — a typical trade-off between accuracy and latency.
</response>

2. **The dataset wasn't uploaded** — The upload may have failed or timed out, leaving no file in the workspace.

4. **Dataset hasn't been registered as a Data Asset** — Even if uploaded, it may not be in the AzureDataAssets container the tool searches.

---

1. **Check your upload history:** If you used Azure ML Studio, go to the "Data" section and look for any files with "precipitation," "rainfall," or "2025" in the name.

2. **Verify exact filename:** Open your local copy of the file and note the exact name (including case and extension), then share it with me.

4. **Dataset hasn't been registered as a Data Asset** — Even if uploaded, it may not be in the AzureDataAssets container the tool searches.

---

### Concrete Next Steps:

1. **Check your upload history:** If you used Azure ML Studio, go to the "Data" section and look for any files with "precipitation," "rainfall," or "2025" in the name.

2. **Verify exact filename:** Open your local copy of the file and note the exact name (including case and extension), then share it with me.

3. **Re-upload if necessary:** If you can't find it, re-upload the dataset to AzureDataAssets and confirm it appears in the workspace before querying.

4. **Try broader queries:** If you recall any part of the name (e.g., "precip", "rain", "global", "2025"), let me know and we can iterate through more combinations.

---

If you can provide any details about the actual filename or how you uploaded it, I can search more precisely!

The data was collected from my apartment unit in San Jose for one plus year. The data is collected with smart meters and shared by the energy company. This is time-series data by nature and can be used for various time-series Machine Learning experiments.

Description of Data
The data contains eight attributes.

TYPE - This is an information column. The value is 'Electric usage' for all the observations.
DATE - Date of electric consumption. There is no timestamp in this field.
START TIME - Start time of the consumption.
END TIME - End time of the consumption
USAGE - Consumption in kWh
UNITS - This column denotes measurement unit. It is kWh for all the observations.
COST - Cost of consumption in $.
NOTES - Mostly an empty column

<summary>
Successfully generated 7-day forecasts using both models:

**Fine-tuned model (Microsoft_Forecaster)**
- Execution time: 6.276 seconds
- Provides uncertainty bounds for all 7 days using the configured 10th/90th percentiles

**Pre-trained baseline (Chronos-bolt-small)**
- Execution time: 1.237 seconds
- Provides uncertainty bounds for all 7 days (temperature/top_k/top_p not used for bolt architecture)

Both models produced valid forecasts with uncertainty intervals, enabling comparison of prediction quality and computational efficiency.
</summary>

**Model & Dataset Analysis:**
- Model 'Microsoft_Forecaster' v1 created 2025-12-17, requires full OHLC (Open, High, Low, Close, Volume, KEY) signature
- Dataset 'Microsoft_Stock': 1,511 rows (2015-04-01 to 2021-03-31), target column = 'Close'

**7-Day Forecasts (Close price):**

| Day | Fine-Tuned Forecast | Fine-Tuned [10th, 90th] | Pre-trained Forecast | Pre-trained [10th, 90th] |
|-----|---------------------|------------------------|----------------------|--------------------------|
| 1   | 235.87              | [232.01, 238.58]       | 235.85               | [231.06, 241.51]         |
| 2   | 234.88              | [233.46, 238.88]       | 236.73               | [230.89, 241.87]         |
| 3   | 236.48              | [233.77, 240.36]       | 236.73               | [230.71, 242.58]         |
| 4   | 236.15              | [232.78, 239.38]       | 237.62               | [230.53, 243.64]         |
| 5   | 237.10              | [235.81, 240.99]       | 237.62               | [230.53, 244.35]         |
| 6   | 238.71              | [233.40, 241.44]       | 237.62               | [230.53, 244.53]         |
| 7   | 239.04              | [235.14, 243.06]       | 238.50               | [230.53, 245.41]         |

**Comparison:**

**(a) Uncertainty Interval Width (Upper - Lower):**
| Day | Fine-Tuned Width | Pre-trained Width |
|-----|------------------|-------------------|
| 1   | 6.57 | 10.45 |
| 2   | 5.42 | 10.98 |
| 3   | 6.59 | 11.87 |
| 4   | 6.60 | 13.11 |
| 5   | 5.18 | 13.82 |
| 6   | 8.04 | 14.00 |
| 7   | 7.92 | 14.88 |

VERAGE | 6.6 | 12.7 |

**(b) Execution Time:**
- Fine-tuned model: 6.28 sec
- Pre-trained baseline: 1.24 sec
- Speedup: pre-trained is 5.1× faster

<summary>
The fine-tuned model delivers tighter uncertainty (avg 6.6 vs 12.7 width) by leveraging market-specific covariates (OHLCV), while the pre-trained bolt model runs 5.1× faster with broader intervals. Trade-off: fine-tuned for narrower confidence when latency is acceptable; pre-trained for speed-critical applications.
</summary>

<feedback>
- Dataset metadata call was seamless and provided essential schema details.
- model_versions and model_details tools worked well, with clear signature information that guided correct inference inputs.
- The fine-tuned model inference correctly matched the full OHLCV/Key signature.
- Pre-trained bolt inference returned expected behavior (sampling parameters not used) and included uncertainty bounds.
- Both APIs returned structured forecasts with quantiles, enabling interval width comparison.
- Tool latency for model lookups was sub-second and for inference was under 6.3 seconds total.
</feedback>

The data was collected from my apartment unit in San Jose for one plus year. The data is collected with smart meters and shared by the energy company. This is time-series data by nature and can be used for various time-series Machine Learning experiments.

Description of Data
The data contains eight attributes.

TYPE - This is an information column. The value is 'Electric usage' for all the observations.
DATE - Date of electric consumption. There is no timestamp in this field.
START TIME - Start time of the consumption.
END TIME - End time of the consumption
USAGE - Consumption in kWh
UNITS - This column denotes measurement unit. It is kWh for all the observations.
COST - Cost of consumption in $.
NOTES - Mostly an empty column

- Default target: Close column

**Dataset Analysis:**
- Microsoft_Stock: 1,511 rows (4/1/2015 - 3/31/2021)
- Columns: Date, Open, High, Low, Close, Volume, KEY

**Forecasts Generated:**
1. Fine-tuned model (7-day forecast with 10th/90th percentiles)
2. Pre-trained baseline (Chronos-Bolt-Small, 7-day forecast with 10th/90th percentiles)
</summary>

<feedback>
- Tools work smoothly for fetching model details and generating forecasts
- Parallel execution of inference calls is efficient
- Both models return清晰的 forecast quantiles as expected
</feedback>

<response>
**Forecast Comparison for 7-Day Microsoft Stock ('Close' Price):**

| Day | Fine-Tuned Forecast | [10th, 90th] Width | Pre-trained Forecast | [10th, 90th] Width |
|-----|---------------------|-------------------|---------------------|-------------------|
| 1 | 234.59 | 4.25 | 235.85 | 10.45 |
| 2 | 235.53 | 5.16 | 236.73 | 10.98 |
| 3 | 235.84 | 4.00 | 236.73 | 11.87 |
| 4 | 236.79 | 5.31 | 237.62 | 13.11 |
| 5 | 237.10 | 6.48 | 237.62 | 13.82 |
| 6 | 236.12 | 4.02 | 237.62 | 14.00 |
| 7 | 236.43 | 5.20 | 238.50 | 14.88 |

**Avg Interval Width | 4.77 | | 12.73 |

**(a) Uncertainty Intervals:**
- **Fine-tuned model**: Tighter intervals (avg width: ~$4.77), indicating higher confidence
- **Pre-trained baseline**: Wider intervals (avg width: ~$12.73) (~2.7× wider), suggesting more uncertainty
- The specialized model demonstrates better calibrated predictions for this domain

**(b) Execution Time:**
- **Fine-tuned model**: 6.37 seconds
- **Pre-trained baseline**: 0.96 seconds (~6.6× faster)
- Trade-off: precision vs. speed

**Summary**: The fine-tuned model provides narrower, more confident predictions at the cost of longer inference time, while the pre-trained model quickly delivers broader estimates with larger uncertainty bounds.

## Dataset Summary
**Microsoft_Stock** contains 1,511 daily records from April 1, 2015 to March 31, 2021 with columns: Date, Open, High, Low, Close, Volume, KEY

**Fields Used for Forecasting:**
- **Date** (time column)
- **Close** (target value - closing stock price)

---

## 10-Day Probabilistic Forecast

| Day | Median (50th %ile) | Lower (10th %ile) | Upper (90th %ile) | Spread (Volatility) |
|-----|-------------------|-------------------|-------------------|---------------------|
| 1   | $235.85           | $231.06           | $241.51           | $10.45              |
| 2   | $236.73           | $230.89           | $241.87           | $10.98              |
| 3   | $236.73           | $230.71           | $242.58           | $11.87              |
| 4   | $237.62           | $230.53           | $243.64           | $13.11              |
| 5   | $237.62           | $230.53           | $244.35           | $13.82              |
| 6   | $237.62           | $230.53           | $244.53           | $14.00              |

| 9   | $239.39           | $230.53           | $247.54           | $17.01              |
| 10  | $239.39           | $230.18           | $248.25           | $18.07              |

---

## Risk Interpretation

**Overall Trend:** The model forecasts a modest upward trajectory from ~$235.85 to ~$239.39 over the 10-day period (+1.5%).

**Volatility Risk:**
- The **prediction spread widens from $10.45 to $18.07** (73% increase), indicating expanding uncertainty over time
- **Downside risk (10th percentile)**: Could dip to ~$230 by day 10 (-7.5% from day 1 close)
- **Upside potential (90th percentile)**: Could rise to ~$248 by day 10 (+3.1% from day 1 close)

**Key Takeaway:** The forecast shows relatively **stable short-term expectations** with low-moderate volatility. The widening spread reflects typical forecast uncertainty—we're more confident about near-term prices than those further out. Conservative traders should note the ~$230 floor (10th percentile) as a potential support level.

</response>

---

<feedback>
The chronos_inference_pretrained tool worked efficiently (1.8 seconds) and returned clean probabilistic forecasts with properly formatted bounds. The ability to customize quantiles (10th/90th for volatility analysis) was exactly what was needed for this risk assessment task.
</feedback>

<summary>
Obtained both forecast results. Analyzing uncertainty interval widths and execution times for comparison.
</summary>

## Model Analysis Summary

### Microsoft_Forecaster (Fine-tuned Model)
- **Version**: 1
- **Created**: 2025-12-17
- **Architecture**: T5-based
- **Input Schema**: Date, Open, High, Low, Close, Volume, KEY (all required)
- **Default Target**: Close
- **Model Size**: ~184 MB

### Comparison Results

| Aspect | Fine-tuned Model | Pre-trained Baseline |
|--------|------------------|---------------------|
| **Execution Time** | 6.39 seconds | 0.87 seconds |
| **Speed Ratio** | ~7.3x slower | Baseline |

### Uncertainty Interval Analysis (10th-90th Percentiles)

**Fine-tuned Model Interval Widths (avg: 6.89):**
- Day 1: 5.54 | Day 2: 6.84 | Day 3: 5.29 | Day 4: 7.77 | Day 5: 6.73 | Day 6: 9.21 | Day 7: 6.88

**Pre-trained Baseline Interval Widths (avg: 12.73):**
- Day 1: 10.45 | Day 2: 10.98 | Day 3: 11.87 | Day 4: 13.11 | Day 5: 13.82 | Day 6: 14.00 | Day 7: 14.88

**Key Findings:**

**(a) Uncertainty Intervals**: The fine-tuned model produces significantly **tighter** uncertainty intervals - approximately **46% narrower** on average (6.89 vs 12.73). This indicates the specialized model has higher confidence in its predictions, likely due to being specifically trained on Microsoft stock patterns and related market features (Open, High, Low, Volume).

**(b) Execution Time**: The pre-trained baseline is substantially **faster** (~0.87s vs 6.39s), running about **7.3x quicker**. This is expected as:
- Fine-tuned model uses a larger T5 architecture with Monte Carlo sampling (20 samples)
- Baseline uses the optimized "bolt" architecture that bypasses expensive sampling operations

### Forecast Values Summary

| Day | Fine-tuned Forecast | Pre-trained Forecast |
|-----|---------------------|---------------------|
| 1 | 235.87 | 235.85 |
| 2 | 236.18 | 236.73 |
| 3 | 236.49 | 236.73 |
| 4 | 236.80 | 237.62 |
| 5 | 237.11 | 237.62 |
| 6 | 237.43 | 237.62 |
| 7 | 237.09 | 238.50 |

Both models show similar upward trends, with mean forecasts averaging ~236.85 across both approaches.

<feedback>
The tools worked well and provided comprehensive results. The model details endpoint returned nested JSON that required careful parsing, but all information was accessible. Both inference functions executed successfully and provided execution time metadata in the response, making performance comparison straightforward. The distinction between T5 (fine-tuned) and bolt (pre-trained) architectures was clear from the outputs.
</feedback>

runs.full_response_text: Step 1: Dataset Investigation - Retrieved metadata for 'Microsoft_Stock' dataset (1,511 rows from April 2015 to March 2021) - Identified relevant forecasting fields: 'Date' (timestamp) and 'Close' (closing price - standard for stock forecasting) Step 2: Probabilistic Forecasting - Used pretrained Chronos-bolt-small model for 10-day forecast - Configured quantiles: median (0.5), lower bound (0.1), upper bound (0.9) - Successfully generated probabilistic predictions The dataset_info tool provided clear field names and descriptions, making it straightforward to identify 'Close' as the target column. The forecast generated quantile bounds as requested, though the timezone/timestamp metadata shows a future date (2026) which may need clarification in production. The forecast values appear reasonable for Microsoft stock, and the probabilistic outputs enable volatility assessment. ## Microsoft Stock — 10-Day Probabilistic Forecast | Day | Median Forecast ($/share) | Lower Bound (10th %ile) | Upper Bound (90th %ile) | Interval Width | % of Median | |-----|---------------------------|-------------------------|-------------------------|----------------|-------------| | 1 | 235.85 | 231.06 | 241.51 | 10.45 | 4.4% | | 2 | 236.73 | 230.89 | 241.87 | 10.98 | 4.6% | | 3 | 236.73 | 230.71 | 242.58 | 11.87 | 5.0% | | 4 | 237.62 | 230.53 | 243.64 | 13.11 | 5.5% | | 5 | 237.62 | 230.53 | 244.35 | 13.82 | 5.8% | | 6 | 237.62 | 230.53 | 244.53 | 14.00 | 5.9% | | 7 | 238.50 | 230.53 | 245.41 | 14.88 | 6.2% | | 8 | 239.39 | 231.24 | 246.65 | 15.41 | 6.4% | | 9 | 239.39 | 230.53 | 247.54 | 17.01 | 7.1% | | 10 | 239.39 | 230.18 | 248.25 | 18.07 | 7.5% | --- ## Risk Interpretation Uptrend with Growing Uncertainty: The model forecasts a modest upward price trajectory, rising approximately from $235.85 to $239.39 over the 10 days (+1.5%). Increasing Volatility: The prediction interval (10th–90th percentile) widens from ~4.4% of the median on day 1 to ~7.5% on day 10, indicating higher uncertainty further into the future. Bounded Downside: The 10th-percentile floor remains near $230 across the horizon, suggesting a relatively contained worst-case scenario. Conversely, the 90th-percentile ceiling rises steadily, highlighting greater upside dispersion. Potential Use: These bounds support risk-based decisions (e.g., stop-loss levels around $230, upside targets near the rising upper bound). The widening intervals warrant conservative position sizing as horizon expands.

result_data.name: Household_Smart_Meter
result_data.description:
The data was collected from my apartment unit in San Jose for one plus year. The data is collected with smart meters and shared by the energy company. This is time-series data by nature and can be used for various time-series Machine Learning experiments.

Description of Data
The data contains eight attributes.

TYPE - This is an information column. The value is 'Electric usage' for all the observations.
DATE - Date of electric consumption. There is no timestamp in this field.

**Overall Risk Profile:** Moderate to elevated risk. While the median trend is positive with gradual upward momentum, the expanding prediction interval signals significant price uncertainty—traders should prepare for potential swings in a ~$9-18 band by the end of the forecast window. The data was collected from my apartment unit in San Jose for one plus year. The data is collected with smart meters and shared by the energy company. This is time-series data by nature and can be used for various time-series Machine Learning experiments.

Description of Data
The data contains eight attributes.

TYPE - This is an information column. The value is 'Electric usage' for all the observations.
DATE - Date of electric consumption. There is no timestamp in this field.
START TIME - Start time of the consumption.
END TIME - End time of the consumption
USAGE - Consumption in kWh
UNITS - This column denotes measurement unit. It is kWh for all the observations.
COST - Cost of consumption in $.
NOTES - Mostly an empty column
